seg.seg: (calls forth), but by no means can it create superiority either for itself or for others in [case of] a lack of wisdom.
Strength, too, will be to the damage of the beings in [case of] a lack of wisdom. Just like, once,
Auch die Stärke gereicht [bzw. wendet sich] den (Mensch)en bei Mangel an Klugheit zum Schaden.
Even strength will turn into a fault for the humans when there is lack of prudence.
Daśagrīva, king of the Rākṣasas, when he saw the town Laṅkā compassed by the Rāma-army, speaks, having gathered his brothers, ministers (and generals(?)):
How should one act? This human, Rāma, son of king Daśaratha has for the sake of Sītā
How should one act? (cf 13)
crossed (the great ocean(?)) and compassed our town Laṅkā. What should now be done with respect to him? Thereupon
(Daśagrīva’s brother, Vibhīṣaṇa,) says to Daśagriva so that all hear [it]: || In the Ṣ.-tune: || (For) the damage(?)
But if (Rāma) can go [away] of his own accord, glad after reaching his object ... to [his] own damage
But if (Rāma) can go [away] of his own accord, glad after reaching his object, (then we will avoid this damage to our own town).
From where does this knowledge come, which [leads] to the destruction of oneself? || Having heard that
because of his lack of wisdom Daśagrīva was very wroth. From his [throne]-seat he tore a (foot(?) of) beryl,
and having thrown it in the face of Vibhīṣana, he says: Give thou this one to Rāma, will you,
whose praise you speak here before me, because I will never give Sītā to Rāma. Whoever of you [pl.] is fearing Rāma,
Because [never] in all my life do I give Sītā to Rāma. (cf 14)
Whoever of you [pl.] is fearing Rāma, I don't fear him.
(Denn ich) gebe in meinem Leben die Sīta dem Rāma nicht. Wenn ihr den Rāma fürchten solltet, (ich) fürchte (nicht).
(For I) will not give Sīta to Rāma in my life. If you should fear Rāma, I (don't) fear [him].
I don’t fear him. || Thereupon Vibhīṣaṇa merely shook(?) his head, [and] wiping the blood away he rose from the gathering, [his] hea(d)
